isis.stitle: HEAT VENTILATION AIR CONDITIONING (HVAC), Thermostatic Expansion Valve (TXV) System, March 2007 and Later - SYSTEM MAINTENANCE - PRE-SEASON SERVICING

svcproc.title: PRE-SEASON SERVICING
svcproc.para: Experience has shown that many unsatisfactory conditions incurred with heating and air conditioning systems result from lack of regular maintenance. Preventive maintenance and cleanliness of all components within the system are extremely important. A complete step-by-step pre-season checkout of the air conditioner/heater system will substantially increase satisfactory operation during the operating season.

step1.para: Check the mounting fasteners of each component for looseness.
Check condition, tension and alignment of all drive belts. Refer to GROUP 12- ENGINE section in the Master Service Manual.
Check condition of heater hoses and engine cooling system hoses. Replace if necessary.
Verify that the vehicle coolant level is correct.
Check refrigerant hose retention and condition. Look for cracks, chafing, or other damage. Inspect all tubing and hoses for dirty or loose connections. All connections must be clean and tight.

note.para: If a patch of oily residue is found at or near a connection it may indicate a refrigerant leak. Note its location in case a system operational test indicates a refrigerant leak or a low refrigerant condition.
Cleanliness of the air conditioner components cannot be over-emphasized. Lack of proper attention in this area is one of the major causes of costly and unsatisfactory unit operation.

caution.para: Never force the fresh/recirculate air door open. If the door position must be changed; turn on key, set mode control to FLOOR, turn off key. Forcing the door will result in a broken door shaft and a costly repair.

step1.para: If the system has an air filter in evaporator housing or at the housing air intake, check the filter element(s) and replace with a new element if necessary. To access the filter in the evaporator housing, refer to REMOVE AND INSTALL, AIR FILTER .

If the system has been operated in severe service conditions (dust and debris) without an air filter at the evaporator housing; check the evaporator core fins for material that could restrict air flow. Clean the evaporator core if necessary. It is possible to inspect and clean the inlet side of the evaporator core through the air inlet on the cowl tray. If a more thorough cleaning is necessary, refer to REMOVE AND INSTALL, EVAPORATOR CORE
to access the evaporator core.

If the system is a heat-only system (no A/C evaporator), and has been operated without an inlet air filter; check the blower fan and heater core for material that could restrict air flow. Clean the blower fan and heater core if necessary. Refer to REMOVE AND INSTALL, BLOWER SCROLL HOUSING
to access the blower assembly and the heater core.

caution.para: When using a pressure washer to clean any heat exchanger (radiator, condenser, evaporator, or charge air cooler); use caution and maintain distance from the component with the pressure washer. Do not spray the component fins at an angle as fin damage may occur and reduce efficiency.

step1.para: Clean all foreign material from condenser and radiator fins. As often as necessary, spray water through the condenser towards the radiator and through the radiator towards the condenser to flush debris from the fins. If necessary, spray the component with a cleaning solution, allow to soak 20 - 30 minutes, then rinse with clean water.
Operate air conditioner system and check operation of controls.
Verify that the system is cooling properly in the A/C modes and heating properly in the heat modes.

Use Diamond Logic Builder (DLB) and the electronic service tool to verify that no HVAC Diagnostic Trouble Codes (DTC's) are currently stored in the system. For complete information on viewing DTC's refer to the applicable Electrical Troubleshooting Guide (on ISIS) for the vehicle being serviced.
